                 stopped

reviews.review_text: Not a great story.  I would have preferred if it wasn't told as him telling a story.  In would have preferred if it had been told as it was happening. Glad it was short as in probably would have put it down after the first couple of chapters.

The story often thrilling is under scored by a genuine fear that over takes the reader of a future that promises nothing when all human efforts is expunged by forces we have no say. Only by the most minute  elements of our nature made by the Creator saves us. When all that is lost is suddenly given back do we have the sense of all we over looked in life is now seen differently. War of the Worlds is more than a thrilling story of invasion but rather an insight to ourselves.

Ralph Ellison takes the reader on a tumultuous journey, following our protagonist, from the moment his troubles began at the Golden Day, till the moment he truly became invisible in the avant-garde, or perhaps the rear, of the underground. This book is as actual in 2017, as it was fifty years ago. Superb read.

Typically, I really enjoy the classics, but H.G. Wells' Invisible Man didn't do it for me.  The story was slow paced, which usually isn't an issue with me, but that was coupled with the fact that the characters and writing were dull.  I lost interest very quickly.
I like big butts and I won't lie, and this did not contain big butts, but the story was rather decent.

This review is for the Kindle version of the Audible edition.The narration was excellent. I find the story to be of shallow imagination, narrow, and short-sighted vision of possibilities open to a person of higher education and strong intelligence such as the protagonist of the story. His avenues of possible options were so common and lacked creativity. What could have been done with such an advantage is far greater than the author perceived and pursued in this rather disappointing story.
This is a great book. His description of the planet's landscape and animal life after the sun starts to die made the hair stand up on the back of my neck. It's beautifully written.

title: Invisible Man

summary:
Invisible Man is a milestone in American literature, a book that has continued to engage readers since its appearance in 1952. A first novel by an unknown writer, it remained on the bestseller list for sixteen weeks, won the National Book Award for fiction, and established Ralph Ellison as one of the key writers of the century.

The nameless narrator of the novel describes growing up in a black community in the South, attending a Negro college from which he is expelled, moving to New York and becoming the chief spokesman of the Harlem branch of "the Brotherhood", and retreating amid violence and confusion to the basement lair of the Invisible Man he imagines himself to be.

The book is a passionate and witty tour de force of style, strongly influenced by T.S. Eliot's The Waste Land, Joyce, and Dostoevsky.
story_arc: Opens with good fortunes, but doomed to fail
